author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Wimbledon, One Final Day of Rest and One Last Manic Monday
description: Starting in 2022, the tournament will eliminate its traditional “middle Sunday” off and instead spread fourth-round matches across Sunday and Monday.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon paused midtournament for the last time on Sunday. The practice courts were busy, but as usual no fans were admitted to the grounds and no official matches were played despite the rare presence of sunshine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 5, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 5, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Prospect of Demolishing Complex That Crumbled Creates New Distress
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 5, 2021.
content: “I’m 58 years old — my whole life is there. I know this is nothing compared to people’s lives, but I also — this is what we have to hold onto.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Wimbledon, the Women’s Quarterfinals Have Just One Past Champ
description: On the tournament’s last Manic Monday, the top-seeded Ashleigh Barty advanced, as did the 2018 winner, Angelique Kerber, who ousted Coco Gauff.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — For nearly an hour on Monday, No. 1 Court was rocking as Emma Raducanu, an 18-year-old from Britain, continued to make the most of her Wimbledon debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Fassler
title: A Call to Diversify Those Calling the Cues
description: New initiatives aim to broaden the pool of stage managers of color and introduce antiracist practices into graduate training.
content: Perhaps the hardest-working people in theater, stage managers oversee all aspects of a production. They work closely with the director to mark down every piece of staging — from where the actors and sets are placed, to the sound and lighting cues. During “tech week,” when a show loads into a theater, they run the rehearsal process to ensure that technical aspects of a production flow smoothly before opening night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krista Langlois
title: Inked Mummies, Linking Tattoo Artists With Their Ancestors
description: As scientists find more tattoos on preserved remains from Indigenous cultures, artists living today are drawing from them to revive cultural traditions.
content: In the 1970s, hunters stumbled upon eight 500-year-old bodies preserved by the Arctic climate near Qilakitsoq, an abandoned Inuit settlement in northwest Greenland. Later, when scientists photographed the mummies with infrared film, they made an intriguing discovery: Five of the six females had delicate lines, dots and arches tattooed on their faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By E. Tammy Kim
title: Amazon Transformed Seattle. Now, Its Workers Are Poised to Take It Back.
description: With the failure of the union campaign in Bessemer still fresh on their minds, labor organizers are looking to retool their strategy.
content: SEATTLE — Prime Day, Amazon’s annual summer shopping bonanza, lasted not one but two days this June. The company advertised it incessantly on social media and especially to subscribers of Amazon Prime, a group that includes close to half of the U.S. population. In the many warehouses in and around the company’s hometown, thousands of workers showed up to their packing and sorting stations for a mandatory, extra-long shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Wimbledon, and British Tennis Fans, See a Rising Star in Emma Raducanu
description: The teenager, a wild-card entry, delighted and surprised in the tournament’s first week. She is part of a growing trend of young women who are showing that experience isn’t everything.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — To book a spot in the second week of Wimbledon, Emma Raducanu had to do something she said she had never done before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘They Need to Realize It’s Not All About the Money’
description: When our columnist asked how the Olympics could be revamped, readers responded with calls to focus on the competition and do away with the corruption and excess that have bloated the Games.
content: Stop the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: America celebrates July 4.
content: On the day long earmarked as a milestone in the fight against the coronavirus, the White House hosted a celebration of about 1,000 people yesterday to commemorate the July 4 holiday and herald the administration’s progress toward overcoming the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Says Pope Is in ‘Good General Condition’ After Colon Surgery
description: The 84-year-old pontiff was “alert” after a three-hour operation, but he is expected to stay in the hospital in Rome for a week.
content: ROME — The Vatican said on Monday that Pope Francis was in “good general condition” a day after undergoing colon surgery, adding that he was expected to remain in the hospital for seven days, “if no complications arise.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: As Lebanon’s Crisis Deepens, Lines for Fuel Grow, and Food and Medicine Are Scarce
description: The World Bank said the financial crisis could rank among the world’s three worst since the mid-1800s. The currency has lost more than 90 percent of its value and unemployment has skyrocketed.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As she sat in the sun in her Mini Cooper inching her way through a long line of cars to get gas, Lynn Husami, 23, tried to use her time well. She had a phone meeting with the adviser of her master’s thesis, called an old friend and played video games on her Nintendo Switch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Peter Zinovieff, Composer and Synthesizer Innovator, Dies at 88
description: His powerful, affordable instruments made memorable sounds for Pink Floyd, Kraftwerk, David Bowie, King Crimson and many others.
content: Peter Zinovieff, a composer and inventor whose pioneering synthesizers shaped albums by Pink Floyd, David Bowie, Roxy Music and Kraftwerk, died on June 23 in Cambridge, England. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Grim Legacy of Cultural Erasure, in Poignant School Photos
description: With the discovery of human remains on the grounds of residential schools, this history is now dominating the conversation in the country.
content: OTTAWA — At times it was the Royal Canadian Mounted Police who came for them. Other times, it was a school van. However it happened, for generations, Indigenous families in Canada had no choice but to send their children to church-run residential schools established by the government to erode their culture and languages, and to assimilate them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Says Autopilot Makes Its Cars Safer. Crash Victims Say It Kills.
description: A California family that lost a 15-year-old boy when a Tesla hit its pickup truck is suing the company, claiming its Autopilot system was partly responsible.
content: Benjamin Maldonado and his teenage son were driving back from a soccer tournament on a California freeway in August 2019 when a truck in front of them slowed. Mr. Maldonado flicked his turn signal and moved right. Within seconds, his Ford Explorer pickup was hit by a Tesla Model 3 that was traveling about 60 miles per hour on Autopilot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Colon Cancer Is Rising in Younger Adults. Do Sugary Drinks Play a Role?
description: As consumption of sugar-laden drinks rose in the 1980s and ’90s, so did colorectal cancer rates among younger adults, a study in nurses found.
content: Colon and rectal cancers are rising in younger adults, though researchers aren’t sure why. A new study of women and diet suggests that sugar-sweetened drinks may play a role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Nations Again Fail to Reach Deal as U.A.E. Demands Higher Quota
description: Monday’s meeting never got started after attempts to mediate the dispute failed to make progress.
content: OPEC, Russia and other major oil producers failed to reach an agreement on proposed production increases on Monday — a third straight day of scheduled meetings without a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A Closer Look at the Colon Condition That Hospitalized the Pope
description: Francis suffered a disorder that is relatively common and treatable, and doctors expect him to make a full recovery.
content: On Sunday evening, Pope Francis underwent surgery for a colon condition called “symptomatic stenotic diverticulitis.” The elective surgery, performed at the Gemelli hospital in Rome, lasted about three hours, according to a statement by the press office of the Holy See.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Schaitkin
title: In Violet Kupersmith’s Novel, a Young Woman Disappears in Saigon
description: The heroine of “Build Your House Around My Body,” a half-Vietnamese American in her 20s, languishes abroad.
content: BUILD YOUR HOUSE AROUND MY BODY By Violet Kupersmith
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Miracle Cures and Magnetic People. Brazil’s Fake News Is Utterly Bizarre.
description: There’s something special about the country’s delirious disinformation.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Hydroxychloroquine is not effective against Covid-19. No. Definitely not. But Brazilians still aren’t sure. After all, just the other day a friend’s cousin forwarded a headline on WhatsApp claiming that all I.C.U. beds in the city of Miracatu are empty because the mayor adopted President Jair Bolsonaro’s “early treatment” — consisting of hydroxychloroquine, ivermectin and azithromycin — for Covid-19. OK, Miracatu does not have a hospital. But still: How can we be sure?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Giulia Heyward and Sophie Kasakove
title: Remainder of a South Florida Condo Building Was Demolished Overnight
description: An arriving tropical storm made demolition using controlled explosives unavoidable following the building collapse, the authorities said.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — For more than a week, as search-and-rescue teams pushed deeper into the heap of concrete and tangled metal that had formed Champlain Towers South before it fell, officials and engineers looked with fear at the portion of the building that still stood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Birthday Parties as Virus Vector
description: Just how much Covid was spreading behind closed doors last year? Quite a lot, as a new study with a simple yet creative approach found out.
content: At the height of the pandemic, it was easy to worry that strangers would give you the virus. But a new study of what happened after people’s birthdays suggests that people we trust were also a common source of viral spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Pennington
title: Who Needs the Grand Canyon? Try a Microadventure.
description: How to find a sense of awe and discover a miraculous world right outside your door.
content: For most people, the first time they see the Grand Canyon or Yosemite Valley or Niagara Falls, their eyes widen, their jaws hit the floor and life is quiet for a moment. In other words, they are in awe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: ‘Maybe We Can Be Friends’: New Yorkers Re-emerge in a Changed City
description: Even as many left the city for the Fourth of July weekend, pockets of activity provided a glimpse of post-pandemic life.
content: This Fourth of July, Iyabo Boyd did two things that she said would have been unthinkable a year ago. She went to a barbecue in a stranger’s yard, and she met new people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Boy, 11, Dies After Raft Overturns in Iowa Amusement Park
description: Four people were hospitalized because of the accident on Saturday at Adventureland Park, near Des Moines.
content: A boy was killed and four people were injured after a raft overturned on a water ride in an Iowa amusement park on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Far-Right Extremist Finds an Ally in an Arizona Congressman
description: Representative Paul Gosar’s association with the white nationalist Nick Fuentes is the most vivid example of the Republican Party’s growing acceptance of extremism.
content: WASHINGTON — Nick Fuentes, the leader of a white nationalist group, was bemoaning the political persecution he said he was facing from the federal government when he paused during a recent livestream to praise one of his few defenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Climate Change Is Making It Harder for Campers to Beat the Heat
description: Burn bans, flashlight campfires, extreme heat and stronger rainstorms: Today’s campers are experiencing their summer fun against the backdrop of climate change.
content: Jill Laidlaw has worked for 37 years at Camp Cavell in Lexington, Mich., a little spot of paradise on Lake Huron. But she has seen trouble in paradise: climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Naomi Osaka Is Talking to the Media Again, but on Her Own Terms
description: The tennis superstar is guest-editing Racquet magazine and has written a cover essay for Time. What’s left for traditional sports journalism?
content: In early May, a couple of weeks before she tweeted that she wouldn’t appear at a required news conference at the French Open, Naomi Osaka was on a Zoom call with a writer for Racquet magazine who was trying to gain insight into the athlete’s inner life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Judas and the Black Messiah’ and Shark Week
description: Shaka King’s historical drama about the Black Panthers airs on HBO. And Discovery spends a week with sharks once again.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: American Internet Giants Hit Back at Hong Kong Doxxing Law
description: A trade group representing Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple and others said changes to a Hong Kong privacy law could stop firms from providing services in the city.
content: An industry group representing the largest American internet companies warned Hong Kong’s government that changes to the city’s data-protection laws could impact companies’ ability to provide services in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: He’s Heir to a Fruit-Juice Empire, but His Main Focus Is Art
description: Eugenio López Alonso divides his time between Los Angeles and Mexico, filling both homes with paintings and sculpture.
content: LOS ANGELES — To your left in the foyer are Damien Hirst’s dots. Over the fireplace is a Louise Bourgeois spider. Opposite the master bed are Cy Twombly’s swirls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: How Bad Are U.S. Wildfires? Even Hawaii Is Battling a Surge.
description: It’s among the wettest places on the planet, but shifts in rainfall, invasive grasses and a housing shortage are driving a wildfire spike on the islands.
content: PA’AUILO, Hawaii — The blaze first swept across parched fields of guinea grass. Then the flames got so close to Emma-Lei Gerrish’s house that she feared for her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Tom Reich, Who Negotiated Big Deals for Baseball Stars, Dies at 82
description: In the early days of free agency, he won multimillion-dollar salaries for players. Among his clients were Sammy Sosa, Ken Griffey and Dock Ellis.
content: Tom Reich, the player agent who became one of baseball’s most powerful figures in the 1970s and 1980s when he negotiated multimillion-dollar deals for many of the game’s greatest stars in the early years of free agency, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Hello, Paris Fashion! Couture Returns With Pieter Mulier’s Alaïa Debut
description: Four years after its founder’s death, the cult brand has a new designer. How did he do?
content: PARIS — On Sunday night in a Paris fizzing with post-lockdown euphoria, in a single-block street in the Marais where the designer Azzedine Alaïa once lived and worked, the first live couture week in a year a half began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: N.H.L. Goalie Dies After Being Hit by Fireworks
description: Matiss Kivlenieks, who played for the Columbus Blue Jackets, died in an accident in Novi, Mich., on Sunday, the police said.
content: Matiss Kivlenieks, a goalie with the Columbus Blue Jackets, died on Sunday after being struck with fireworks at a private party in Novi, Mich., the authorities said. He was 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.3 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor-style home on the Palos Verdes Peninsula, a Craftsman-inspired retreat in Laguna Beach and a 1975 post-and-beam house in Mill Valley.
content: The Palos Verdes Peninsula, in the southwestern part of Los Angeles County, is known for its sweeping ocean views and quiet, family-friendly neighborhoods. This house is in Palos Verdes Estates, a city whose master plan was done by the landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. in the early 1920s. A few blocks away is the Palos Verdes Estates Shoreline Preserve, a cliff-side park with hiking trails and views of the Santa Monica Bay and coastline. Also within walking distance is Palos Verdes High School, a well-ranked public school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Make Melissa Clark’s latest, a sheet-pan chicken with roasted, caramelized zucchini and basil.
content: Good morning. It’s high summer — really high summer, for some of us — and a day off for many, a chance to cook and eat outside. Maybe pan bagnats to wrap in wax paper and slip into a tote bag with a sweating bottle of wine, a few plastic cups, a knife for a big, chilled watermelon? I could eat that meal on a berm beside the highway, steam billowing out of my vehicle’s radiator, and still have a smile on my face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: They Were the Nice, Older Couple Next Door. Then the First Body Turned Up.
description: An Iranian couple has confessed to murdering and dismembering their son, years after killing a daughter and her husband. They are not sorry.
content: The older couple first came to the public eye on a winter night in Tehran, when their film director son invited them to the stage after a screening. They were frail, and seemingly shy, and the younger man helped his mother up the stairs, then draped his arm around his father’s shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: China Won’t Bury Us, Either
description: Appearances of strength obscure realities of weakness, hidden cracks behind imposing facades.
content: Garry Kasparov has a pithy way of summing up the past 18 months of tribulation. “China gave us the virus,” the chess and human-rights champion told me over a recent breakfast. “And the free world gave us the vaccines.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Golf Pro Among 3 Dead After Shooting at Georgia Country Club, Police Say
description: After a golf pro was shot in the head by a man who had driven a truck onto a Kennesaw golf course, two other bodies were found in the bed of the pickup, the authorities said.
content: A golf pro at a suburban Atlanta country club was shot and killed on Saturday by a man who drove onto the golf course in a pickup truck bearing the bodies of two other men in the bed of the vehicle, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kmele Foster, David French, Jason Stanley and Thomas Chatterton Williams
title: Anti-Critical Race Theory Laws Are Un-American
description: We differ in our views on critical race theory. But we agree that the current attempts to ban it from K-12 education are misguided and dangerous.
content: What is the purpose of a liberal education? This is the question at the heart of a bitter debate that has been roiling the nation for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Is Gone, Sort of. The Fireworks Are Still Going Off.
description: The Supreme Court, Congress, even the White House — the reverberations are everywhere.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Hope you had a nice Fourth of July. Politically speaking, most of the fireworks seemed to be coming from the Supreme Court. Any thoughts on how the term ended?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: No Semifinalist Is an Island
description: Denmark and Italy borrowed ideas from Spain. Spain has learned from Germany. And England has taken everything it can from anywhere it can get it.
content: LEEDS, England — Kalvin Phillips came home, for the first time, as a fully fledged England international with four jerseys as souvenirs. He had asked his new teammates to autograph one, destined to be framed and mounted on a wall at home. Two others were reserved for his mother and grandmother, as tokens of gratitude for years of support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volkswagen Sheds Bugatti, Maker of Over-the-Top Sports Cars
description: Despite sticker prices in the millions, the storied brand chronically lost money. The Croatian firm Rimac will take a controlling interest.
content: Volkswagen said Monday that it was giving up control of Bugatti, the storied automaker whose absurdly expensive hypercars are worshiped by aficionados but seemed incongruous at a company better known for economical Golfs and Passats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Richard Donner, Director of ‘Superman’ and ‘Lethal Weapon’ Films, Dies at 91
description: The Bronx-born Mr. Donner was in his late 40s when he made his first megahit, about the Man of Steel, but others soon followed, including “The Goonies” and “Scrooged.”
content: Richard Donner, the tough, single-minded but playful film director who made Christopher Reeve’s Superman fly, Mel Gibson’s deranged detective lethal and the young stars of “The Goonies” pirate-adorable, died on Monday. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Challenges of Bipolar Disorder in Young People
description: Symptoms in children may initially be mistaken for other conditions, and young people may suffer serious distress for years.
content: I was doing research and interviews on bipolar disorder when notices appeared in my Brooklyn neighborhood about a 21-year-old man who had been missing for a week. He was described as “bipolar” and “may be experiencing a manic episode.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: England to Lift Most Virus Restrictions, Including Those for Masks
description: Critics dismissed as “absolutely ridiculous” the idea that people will continue to wear masks voluntarily on trains and in crowded indoor spaces.
content: LONDON — As Britain forges ahead with reopening its economy after 16 months of virus-driven restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a backlash over an issue that has vexed the country’s response to the pandemic from the start: whether to require people to wear face masks indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley
title: Japanese Resort Town Searching for 80 People After Mudslide
description: Four victims have been declared dead, and the authorities are trying to determine whether the dozens of missing were caught up in a disaster set off by record rains.
content: TOKYO — Officials in the Japanese resort town of Atami said on Monday that they were still trying to locate more than 80 people after record-setting rains had brought a mudslide crashing through a residential area over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Terry Donahue, Who Led U.C.L.A. to Bowl Victories, Dies at 77
description: Over 20 years, he had more wins than any football coach in the school’s history, including seven consecutive bowl championships.
content: Terry Donahue, who became the face of football at U.C.L.A. as a player and coach, staying in the latter position for 20 years and leading the school to seven consecutive bowl-winning seasons in the 1980s, died on Sunday at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Reichel and Robyn Huang
title: Inside a Peyote Pilgrimage
description: Drug tourists, mining companies and farming encroachment are threatening the Wixárika people’s annual hunt for the psychedelic plant in the Mexican desert.
content: Mario Bautista was digging relentlessly at the ground. Deep in the vast and unforgiving Chihuahuan Desert, in northeastern Mexico, he had spent nearly eight hours wading through a seemingly endless patch of thorny brush. Surrounding him were 25 members of his community, including his wife and children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Everything I Know About Hope I Learned From My Dog
description: In any household, the true master of hope is the family dog.
content: NASHVILLE — The bad-luck streak started when I got Covid-19 and then it escalated: health troubles, deaths in the extended family, frantic worry about loved ones, too many of whom were struggling in the pandemic. All of it backgrounded by dire news about the natural world and my own beloved country. There have been times during the last 16 months when I wondered whether grief and fear were all I would ever feel again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
title: A Jailed Priest’s Death in India Stirs Outrage
description: The Rev. Stan Swamy was among more than a dozen activists jailed under a broad antiterrorism law that critics say is used to stifle dissent.
content: NEW DELHI — A Jesuit priest and activist with Parkinson’s disease, whose high-profile arrest  was seen as an example of the broad scope of the Indian government’s unpopular antiterrorism law, died on Monday still in custody at a hospital in Mumbai, his lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: It’s Morning in Joe Biden’s America
description: And the president deserves a lot of the credit.
content: Last Tuesday President Biden’s Council of Economic Advisers published a blog post warning everyone not to make too much of any one month’s employment report. It presumably released this in advance of Friday’s report to fend off possible accusations that it was just trying to make excuses for a weak number. As it happened, however, the report came in strong: The economy added an impressive 850,000 jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Rick Rojas
title: After Condo Is Demolished, More Bodies Are Found in the Rubble
description: Search efforts were paused because of fears of another collapse at the building in Surfside, Fla., but resumed on Monday after a controlled demolition.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — With nearly half of the building no longer looming over them, rescuers resumed searching the rubble of a collapsed condominium complex north of Miami Beach on Monday, finding four more bodies and bringing the death toll to 28 in the hours after the still-standing portion of Champlain Towers South was leveled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At Wimbledon, Felix Auger-Aliassime and Denis Shapovalov Stir a Nation
description: The young Canadians advanced on Monday to the men’s singles quarterfinals, one in easy straight sets, and the other in a gutty five-set victory. It feels like 2014.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — As the Montreal Canadiens, Canada’s hope for hockey’s Stanley Cup, faced elimination across an ocean, the compatriots Denis Shapovalov and Felix Auger-Aliassime broke through to their first Wimbledon quarterfinals within hours of each other on Monday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Gifted Writer Returns With a Supremely Harrowing Novel
description: In Carolyn Ferrell’s “Dear Miss Metropolitan,” three young girls are kidnapped and kept in a decaying house in Queens for a decade.
content: This novel has been a long time coming. Carolyn Ferrell first emerged on radar screens in 1997 with “Don’t Erase Me,” a book of stories, many about the spiritual if not material resources of underachieving but buoyant and street-smart young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China’s crackdown on Didi.
content: China’s government ordered the country’s leading ride-hailing platform, Didi, removed from app stores for “serious” problems related to the collection and use of customer data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: The Liberty’s Role in Making W.N.B.A. Players ‘Top Dogs’ of Activism
description: Five years ago, players were fined for wearing unapproved shirts to protest the fatal shootings of two Black men. The league has since embraced players’ desire to speak out against social injustice.
content: On June 22, the Liberty hosted a game celebrating Juneteenth. Some players wore Black Lives Matter T-shirts during shootaround, and the night’s festivities began with a rendition of “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” often considered the national anthem of Black Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Juul Is Fighting to Keep Its E-Cigarettes on the U.S. Market
description: The company faces declining sales and thousands of lawsuits claiming it knowingly sold its trendy vaping products to minors. Soon the F.D.A. will decide whether it can keep selling them at all.
content: Sales have plunged by $500 million. The work force has been cut by three-quarters. Operations in 14 countries have been abandoned. Many state and local lobbying campaigns have been shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China’s Crackdown on Didi Is a Reminder That Beijing Is in Charge
description: After targeting the ride-hailing platform days after its I.P.O., regulators on Monday moved against more companies that had recently been listed on Wall Street.
content: In less than a week, China’s leading ride-hailing platform, Didi, has gone from investor darling with a megabucks Wall Street debut to the biggest new target in Beijing’s fast-moving efforts to tame the country’s internet industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Maynard
title: A ‘Broken Home’ Didn’t Break Me, or My Kids
description: Three decades after her divorce, the novelist Joyce Maynard celebrates what would have been her 44th wedding anniversary.
content: At the time my first husband and I parted — 1989, in our 30s, after 12 years of marriage — a hugely popular book about the negative impact of divorce on children was going the rounds on the talk show circuit. Its author — a psychologist who’d conducted a study on the children of divorced couples from Marin County, Calif. — suggested that for children whose parents split up, the damage could endure for decades. No terror I could have imagined at the time held more power than the psychologist’s dire prediction, that children deprived of the opportunity to grow up in “an intact family” would suffer low performance in school, difficulty in making commitments and forming healthy relationships, and a high incidence of divorce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Moving Downtown, to the Center of the Action
description: A breakup during the pandemic sent him home to Long Island, where he recharged and decided the Upper East Side was just too quiet.
content: In the corner of Chris Keyloun’s new apartment downtown there is a disco ball resting in a large wooden bowl. It looks a little worn out, some of the mirrored rectangles cracked, others completely broken off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar, Yousur Al-Hlou and Aliza Aufrichtig
title: Stripped, Groped and Violated: Egyptian Women Describe Abuse by the State
description: Speaking publicly for the first time, these Egyptian women say they were sexually abused during invasive searches and medical exams by government authorities.
content: Speaking publicly for the first time, these Egyptian women say they were sexually abused during invasive searches and medical exams by government authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Rep. Adam Kinzinger on the Moral Failure of Republicans and the Big Lie
description: “If you’re scared to tell the truth to people, I understand, but you need to find a different line of work.”
content: “If you’re scared to tell the truth to people, I understand, but you need to find a different line of work.”

title: What You Get for $3.3 Million in California
description: A Tudor-style home on the Palos Verdes Peninsula, a Craftsman-inspired retreat in Laguna Beach and a 1975 post-and-beam house in Mill Valley.

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Looks Toward ‘Declaring our Independence’ From the Coronavirus
description: President Biden lauded the nation’s progress against the pandemic during an Independence Day celebration at the White House, saying that getting vaccinated is “the most patriotic thing you can do.”
